citations.narrative:
Records of acquisition and disposition were incomplete for animals recently acquired or sold. Disposition records were
missing for a group of animals who left the facility on June 1, 2023 including a coati and a wallaby. Records of acquisition
were incomplete for sheep and goats recently acquired by the facility. The incomplete records lacked the name, address,
and/or USDA license number or driver's license number for buyers and sellers of the animals. Accurate recordkeeping is
important for veterinary oversight and animal traceability in the event of disease outbreaks or stolen animals. Correct by
maintaining accurate and complete records of acquisition and disposition in accordance with the Animal Welfare Act.

An enclosure housing 3 ring-tailed lemurs (2 adults and 1 juvenile) contains sharp points that may injure the primates. The
inner surface of the enclosure wall closest to the feed shed has wires with sharp points and some gaps where sections of
wire/mesh do not come together fully. Sharp points and gaps may cause a lemur to become entangled or scratched.
Correct by 6/30/23 by ensuring that lemurs and any other nonhuman primates are housed in enclosures that do not
contain sharp points or gaps where animals could become entangled.

The primary enclosure housing 4 kangaroo and 4 wallaby is not enclosed by the perimeter fence. A perimeter fence is
important for containing the animals if they escape from their primary enclosure, and is important for preventing contact
between the kangaroos and wallaby's and any unauthorized people or stray animals. Correct by 7/21/23 by housing
kangaroo and wallaby in an enclosure that is contained within a perimeter fence that is at least 6 feet tall and at least 3
feet away from the primary enclosure, or by obtaining a variance approved by the Administrator.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Safari Park Manager.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Records of acquisition and disposition were incomplete for animals recently acquired or sold. Disposition records were 
missing for a group of animals who left the facility on June 1, 2023 including a coati and a wallaby. Records of acquisition 
were incomplete for sheep and goats recently acquired by the facility. The incomplete records lacked the name, address, 
and/or USDA license number or driver's license number for buyers and sellers of the animals. Accurate recordkeeping is 
important for veterinary oversight and animal traceability in the event of disease outbreaks or stolen animals. Correct by 
maintaining accurate and complete records of acquisition and disposition in accordance with the Animal Welfare Act. 
3.80(a)(2)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An enclosure housing 3 ring-tailed lemurs (2 adults and 1 juvenile) contains sharp points that may injure the primates. The 
inner surface of the enclosure wall closest to the feed shed has wires with sharp points and some gaps where sections of 
wire/mesh do not come together fully. Sharp points and gaps may cause a lemur to become entangled or scratched. 
Correct by 6/30/23 by ensuring that lemurs and any other nonhuman primates are housed in enclosures that do not 
contain sharp points or gaps where animals could become entangled. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The primary enclosure housing 4 kangaroo and 4 wallaby is not enclosed by the perimeter fence. A perimeter fence is 
important for containing the animals if they escape from their primary enclosure, and is important for preventing contact 
between the kangaroos and wallaby's and any unauthorized people or stray animals. Correct by 7/21/23 by housing 
kangaroo and wallaby in an enclosure that is contained within a perimeter fence that is at least 6 feet tall and at least 3 
feet away from the primary enclosure, or by obtaining a variance approved by the Administrator. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Safari Park Manager.
